custom.promptingTitle: How to Write a Great Kling 3 Standard Prompt
custom.promptingIntro: Kling 3 Standard performs best with shot-based direction: clear framing, one action per shot, explicit motion, and (if audio is on) short dialogue plus minimal sound cues.
promptingGlobalPrinciples: Think in shots, not clips: one action per shot is easier to execute cleanly.
Anchor your subjects early (and reuse the same wording) to reduce drift across shots.
Put framing + camera movement before style adjectives.
If audio is on: keep dialogue short and add only 1–2 sound cues.
promptingEngineWhy: Multi-shot works best with 2–4 shots; keep each shot to one readable action.
Elements improve continuity: reference @Element1/@Element2 consistently across the prompt.
Voice IDs: reference voices in the prompt as <<<voice_1>>> and <<<voice_2>>> (max 2 voices).
Audio output supports English and Chinese; other languages may be auto-translated to English when audio is enabled.
End frame helps land transitions; avoid adding new actions in the final second.

promptingTabNotes.quick: Quick = variations. Use for fast iteration.
promptingTabNotes.structured: Structured = consistency. Use when you need reliable results.
promptingTabNotes.pro: Pro = control. Use for precise, repeatable looks.
promptingTabNotes.storyboard: Storyboard = shot timing. Use for multi-shot beats.

promptingTabs.label: Quick
promptingTabs.title: Quick prompt (fast iteration)
promptingTabs.description: Use 1–2 sentences when you want variations.
promptingTabs.copy:
[One subject] [one visible action] in [setting], [framing + one camera move], [lighting/style].
Audio (optional): [ambience + 1 SFX cue OR one short line].
Negative: no text, no logos, no subtitles/overlays.

promptingTabs.label: Structured
promptingTabs.title: Structured prompt (best for reliable results)
promptingTabs.description: Separate information so the model can follow it consistently.
promptingTabs.copy:
Scene anchors:
[Subject + wardrobe/props + 2–3 environment anchors.]

Shots (multi-shot):
Shot 1 (0–5s): [framing + action + one camera move]
Shot 2 (5–10s): [framing + action + one camera move]
Shot 3 (10–15s): [final action/reveal + settle or end frame]

Elements (optional):
@Element1 = [main character]
@Element2 = [prop/product]

Audio (optional):
Dialogue: <<<voice_1>>> “Short line.”
Ambience + 1–2 SFX cues. Keep it minimal.

Constraints:
No logos. No readable text. No subtitles/overlays.

promptingTabs.label: Pro
promptingTabs.title: Pro prompt (ultra-specific "film crew brief")
promptingTabs.description: Use this when you need a very specific cinematic look or continuity across shots.
promptingTabs.copy:
Director brief:
[Goal + vibe + intended audience.]

Continuity (repeat across shots):
- Subject identity + wardrobe/props
- Location + time + 3 visual anchors
- Lighting + palette anchors
- Lens feel + one camera move per shot

Multi-shot plan (up to 15s total):
Shot 1: [framing + action + camera]
Shot 2: [framing + action + camera]
Shot 3: [framing + action + camera]
(optional) Shot 4–6: [only if needed]

Elements:
@Element1 = [character]
@Element2 = [product/prop]

Audio (if on):
Dialogue: <<<voice_1>>> “One short line.”
Ambience + 1–2 SFX cues + optional music vibe.

Negative:
No text, no logos, no subtitles/overlays, no jump cuts.

promptingTabs.label: Storyboard
promptingTabs.title: Storyboard prompt (multi-shot / shot list)
promptingTabs.description: Use this when you want a mini-story in one clip. A storyboard prompt (aka multi-shot / shot list prompt) gives clear timing, camera direction, and continuity. Also called shot-list or sequenced prompts.
promptingTabs.copy:
Duration: [3–15s] • Aspect: [16:9 / 9:16 / 1:1] • Audio: [on/off]

Elements (optional):
@Element1 = [main character/subject]
@Element2 = [prop/product]

Shot 1 (0–3s):
[Framing + action + camera move]

Shot 2 (3–8s):
[Framing + action + camera move]

Shot 3 (8–15s):
[Final action/reveal + camera settle]
End frame (optional): [describe the final frame you want to land on]

Audio (if on):
Dialogue: <<<voice_1>>> “Short line.”
Ambience + 1–2 SFX cues.

Constraints:
No logos. No readable text. No subtitles/overlays. Keep it to one action per shot.

custom.tipsIntro: Kling 3 Standard is most predictable when you plan it like a storyboard: simple shots, consistent elements, and short dialogue.
strengths: 3–15s clips with 2–4 shots and clear timestamps/shot labels.
Use Elements for characters/props you want to keep stable.
For audio: one short line + ambience + 1 key SFX (keep it minimal).
Use an end frame when you need a clean landing or match cut.
troubleshootingItems: Drift across shots → repeat anchors + use @Element references; simplify each shot to one action.
Camera feels chaotic → one move per shot; avoid “dynamic” wording; specify “smooth track” or “tripod-stable”.
Dialogue/lip sync drifts → shorten lines; reduce fast head turns; keep the shot calmer.
Random text/logos → strengthen negative (“no text, no logos, no UI”) and keep signage out of frame.
boundaries: Short-form only (up to 15s); stitch for longer narratives.
Voice IDs are limited (max 2) and audio language behavior depends on routing.
End frame is optional and works best when the final composition is clearly described.
